messages: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:45): Ergh‚Ä¶
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (13:45): doesn't want to sign up to another bug tracker to report a bug in Validator.nu
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:02): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: You mean something like, um, /<!--[^>]*(?<!-->)>([^>]|(?<!-->)>)*$/ perhaps?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:03): Whoops, not that one
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:07): If that matches "<!-- foo > bar" and <!-- foo>" but not "<!-- foo > bar -->"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:08): It does
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:08): should take this opportunity to hook his grep tool up to his new set of pages...
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:08): Ah, well that sounds like what I want then
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:09): notes that "(?<!--)" confusingly has nothing to do with the string "<!--", it's just a negative lookbehind assertion on the string "--"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:10): Ah, that makes a little more sense
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:10): And this is why you shouldn't use regex to parse HTML P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:10): * :P
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:11): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: No this is why should shouldn't have ultra-weird comment parsing
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:11): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: It's saner than SGML.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:11): which requires lookhead
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:13): I don't. I have perfectly sane comment parsing, thank you very much.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:14): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: You use a sophisticated biological neural network to parse comments and it's not even that reliable. How can you describe that as sane?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:14): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Through my own insaity.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:14): *insanity.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:18): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Parsing it's easy, it's just like /<!(-?>|--.*?-->)/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:19): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Parsing it's easy, it's just like /<!(-?>|([^-]|--).*?-->)/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:19): or something like that
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:20): but anyway it's easy
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:20): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I'm looking at the class="" bug now
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:20): The difficulty is trying to match things that are *not* matched by the normal state machine
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:32): How the hell do you get script to validate in HTML 4.01?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:32): stabs SGML
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:35): Use <script src>
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:35): If you want inline scripts, use <script src="data:text/javascript,...">
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:38): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Just rephrase all your less-than tests :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:47): from the HTML4 spec, I can't tell whether id and class are allowed to be empty or not
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:51): It says "must begin with a letter" for id
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:52): But it's taken from the SGML spec, so would probably have to look there
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:54): hmm, the XHTML DTD defines the value of class as NMTOKENS
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:54): Yay! More undocumented differences between XHTML 1.0 and HTML 4.01!
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:56): I think as far as the HTML4 and XHTML1 specs are concerned, the value of class can't be empty
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:56): Can't class be a list of zero class names?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:57): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: not as far as I can see, as far as XML goes
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:58): http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#NT-Nmtoken
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:58): Nmtokens    ::=    Nmtoken (#x20 Nmtoken)*
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:58): Nmtoken    ::=    (NameChar)+
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:58): and XHTML1 DTD says:
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (14:59): Fair enough. Where does it say it's NMTOKENS? xhtml1 says CDATA where I'm looking
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:59): "class        NMTOKENS                 #IMPLIED
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (14:59): I'm looking at a DTD on my local system
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:00): XHTML Modularization
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:00): Well, it claims to be an XHTML 1.0 schema, not an XHTML Mod. one
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:01): What I found: http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/dtds.html#dtdentry_xhtml1-strict.dtd_coreattrs
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:01): I guess it's obsolete
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:01): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: yeah, that's what I'm looking at now
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:01): well, it's right, even if it's obsolete
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:02): and XHTML modularization is wrong
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:02): I mean, in practice at least
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:02): YSOD on empty class attribute? :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:02): YSOD?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:03): Yellow screen of death
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:06): the HTML 4.01 DTD used by the W3C validator says "class       CDATA          #IMPLIED"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:07): and all the XHTML1 DTDs it uses says the same
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:08): but the XHTML 1.1 DTD it uses says "class        NMTOKENS                 #IMPLIED"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:08): so those mooncalfs apparently redefined it in XHTML 1.1
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:09): I think in in validator.nu we should preserve that brokenness
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:10): to learn people not to bother validating against XHTML 1.1
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:11): but I see hsivonen had the foresight to not even include an XHTML1.1-checking option in validator.nu
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:12): I wonder if they bothered to document this in the XHTML 1.1 spec
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:13): nope
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (15:13): http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml11/changes.html#a_changes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:22): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: With that search thing, how many results do you want?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:26): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Actually, you can have them all
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:27): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: http://philip.html5.org/data/comments-not-closed-but-with-a-gt-after-them.txt
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:30): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Great, thanks
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:38): hopes his regexp isn't wrong
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:46): hasn't checked yet
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:47): <!doctype html> seems to be one of those most popular HTML5 features
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:47): sees it on 64 distinct domains
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:48): like last.fm and pear.php.net and maps.google.com and edward.oconnor.cx and help.godaddy.com
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:49): s/those most/the most/
